title: Ahaz's Reign and Idolatry
shortSummary: This chapter details the reign of King Ahaz of Judah, highlighting his unfaithfulness to God through idolatry and alliances with foreign powers. It records his political struggles, including the siege of Jerusalem and his appeal to Assyria for help, which led to significant religious compromises. The chapter serves as a sobering example of the consequences of turning away from God and trusting in worldly powers.
timeline: c. 735-719 BC - Reign of King Ahaz in Judah during the Syro-Ephraimite War

keyCharacters.name: Ahaz
keyCharacters.description: King of Judah who reigned for sixteen years; known for his wickedness, idolatry, and reliance on Assyria rather than God.

keyCharacters.name: Pekah
keyCharacters.description: Son of Remaliah and king of Israel; allied with Syria to wage war against Judah.

keyCharacters.name: Rezin
keyCharacters.description: King of Syria who allied with Pekah to attack Jerusalem and later lost Elath to Assyria.

keyCharacters.name: Tiglathpileser
keyCharacters.description: King of Assyria who responded to Ahaz’s plea for help by attacking Syria and Israel.

keyCharacters.name: Urijah
keyCharacters.description: Priest who constructed the altar in Jerusalem according to the pattern Ahaz sent from Damascus.

definitions.definition: An idolatrous practice involving child sacrifice or ritual fire-walking, condemned by God as an abomination.
Elevated sites used for pagan worship and sacrifices, often condemned in Scripture as places of idolatry.
A basin used for ceremonial washing in the temple, symbolizing purification before worship.
The bronze altar used for burnt offerings in the temple, central to Israelite worship.

outline.heading: Ahaz’s Wicked Reign and Idolatry
outline.description: Ahaz begins his reign at age twenty and quickly departs from the ways of David, engaging in idolatrous practices including child sacrifice and worship at high places, demonstrating spiritual unfaithfulness.

outline.heading: War and Siege by Syria and Israel
outline.description: Rezin king of Syria and Pekah king of Israel besiege Jerusalem but fail to capture it; Syria regains control of Elath, pushing out the Jews.

outline.heading: Ahaz’s Alliance with Assyria
outline.description: Ahaz appeals to Tiglathpileser king of Assyria for military aid, sending treasures from the temple as tribute, resulting in the capture of Damascus and death of Rezin.

outline.heading: Religious Reforms and the New Altar
outline.description: Ahaz copies the altar he saw in Damascus, instructing the priest Urijah to build it in Jerusalem, altering the temple worship and introducing foreign religious elements.

outline.heading: Alterations to the Temple and Ahaz’s Death
outline.description: Ahaz removes sacred temple furnishings and dedicates parts of the temple for Assyrian use; the chapter closes with his death and the succession of his son Hezekiah.

application: Trust in God rather than worldly powers, as Ahaz’s reliance on Assyria led to spiritual compromise and national decline.
Avoid syncretism and idolatry by faithfully adhering to God’s prescribed worship and rejecting foreign religious influences.
Recognize the consequences of disobedience and unfaithfulness, using Ahaz’s example as a warning to remain steadfast in the Lord.
Seek godly leadership and pray for rulers who honor God’s commands and lead the people in righteousness.

keyVerses.text: Twenty years old was Ahaz when he began to reign, and reigned sixteen years in Jerusalem, and did not that which was right in the sight of the LORD his God, like David his father.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights Ahaz’s failure to follow God’s ways, setting the tone for the chapter’s account of his wicked reign.

keyVerses.text: So Ahaz sent messengers to Tiglathpileser king of Assyria, saying, I am thy servant and thy son: come up, and save me out of the hand of the king of Syria, and out of the hand of the king of Israel, which rise up against me.
keyVerses.significance: This verse shows Ahaz’s political alliance with Assyria, demonstrating his reliance on human power rather than trusting God.

keyVerses.text: But he walked in the way of the kings of Israel, yea, and made his son to pass through the fire, according to the abominations of the heathen, whom the LORD cast out from before the children of Israel.
keyVerses.significance: This verse reveals the depth of Ahaz’s idolatry, including child sacrifice, which was explicitly condemned by God.

keyVerses.text: And Ahaz slept with his fathers, and was buried with his fathers in the city of David: and Hezekiah his son reigned in his stead.
keyVerses.significance: This verse marks the end of Ahaz’s troubled reign and introduces Hezekiah, who would later lead Judah back to faithful worship.
